newsitem.title: JAPAN: Mitsubishi device to cut diesel emissions.
newsitem.headline: Mitsubishi device to cut diesel emissions.

text.p: Mitsubishi Motors Corp said on Tuesday it has developed a system to eliminate 80 percent of the particle emissions from diesel engines.
The system called "Mitsubishi DPF" consists of a ceramic filter that retrieves particulate matter and a heater for burning up the retrieved particles.
The system will reduce emissions of particulates to 0.125 gram/kilowatt hour, sharply lower than Japan's long-term regulation, effective October 1998, which sets a limit of 0.25 gram/kwh.
It can eliminate virtually 100 percent of the black smoke emitted from diesel engines.

The system, which does not clear nitrogen oxide, will cost about 4.5 million yen ($39,790) for each unit. Mitsubishi will supply 30 systems for installation in Yokohama city's buses by the end of March 1997. ($1=113.1 Yen)
